7.2 Determiners decomposed

Normally when we think about determiners we think about them as being
fixed unary linguistic objects that have dedicated semantic roles, but
is this so? Take the property of being a referring expression, for
example. We have spoken about whether descriptions are referring
expressions or not, but perhaps it is incorrect to suppose that there
are dedicated referring expressions in natural language. Ahn (2019)
argues that what is called on to refer can vary greatly in natural
language, and that what expressions are deployed in order to refer
depends on what else is available to do the job. She proposes a
“competition mechanism” which determines which expression
might be deployed in order to refer to something.  In some cases
it might be a name, in some a demonstrative, in some a pronoun, and in
some a description.  It depends on which expression wins the
competition in that setting. What this means, if correct, is that the
job of reference would not be associated with a single type of
syntactic object, but with a large array of syntactic objects. In a
similar vein, Ludlow and Živanovic (2022) have suggested that what
counts as quantificational may not be a property of individual
morphological items, but is more likely a global structural
property.  In this instance, the definite and indefinite
determiners play more of a role as structure builders and not as
individual operators. The kind of quantificational structure that
emerges would be a function of the surrounding syntactic objects.

It could also be the case that syntactic objects like the definite and
indefinite determiners may not even be as syntactically simple as they
appear.  As noted above, Schwarz (2009) observed that there are
languages in which morphologically distinct words are used to express
uniqueness and familiarity. Following Stake (2009) and others working
in “nanosyntax,” this would create some pressure to say
that the definite determiner in English might not be a single
functional head, but is “smeared” across a larger phrase
structure that has separate functional heads for expressing uniqueness
and familiarity.  The English determiner ends up being
exploded across the phrase structure.
